title: Contributing to ConFluxPro
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("valentingar/ConFluxPro", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: ConFluxPro
text: Hello welcome ConFluxPro - toolkit soil gas analysis. package implements Flux-Gradient Method (FGM) model soil gas fluxes concentration profiles. provides range functions cover complete process raw data modeling fluxes beyond. “ConFluxPro” stands Concentration, Flux Production - three levels integration gases soil. vignette provides overview package structure, including important functions general workflow.

title: ConFluxPro
text: Modeling gas fluxes ConFluxPro modular straightforward. Starting data preparation, collect necessary data compatible way combine single model frame cfp_dat(). , calculating flux rates simple calling single function. fg_flux() implements different ‘forward’ methods derive flux rates, pro_flux() calls inverse model. returned model result, can extract efflux() production() rates within soil perform different post-hoc analyses calibrating model alternate() deriving estimate model uncertainty bootstrap_error(). aspect workflow explained detail articles documentation. Create cfp_dat() data set: vignette("data_preparation", package = "ConFluxPro") Basic modeling fg_flux() pro_flux(): vignette("flux", package = "ConFluxPro") Parameter variation calibration alternate(): vignette("calibration", package = "ConFluxPro") Uncertainty estimation bootstrap_error(): vignette("uncertainty", package = "ConFluxPro")

Finally, reverse also possible combine_models() automatically joins different datasets compatible.

title: Calibration
text: Different input parameters flux-gradient method (FGM) affect modeled effluxes different extent. importantly, soil physics defined soilphys can significant measurement sampling uncertainties. derived DS values often require many input parameters therefore high uncertainty. time,DS large effect modeled efflux, leading potential offsets biases. following approach aims quantify effects calibrate ConFluxPro models. mostly intended used inverse models pro_flux() method. basic idea modify values input parameters within given range re-run models quantify effect efflux. second step, different parameters model quality can calculated select model runs lowest model error. Programatically, mainly interact three functions: cfp_run_map() generate plan modify model run, alterante() actually run models evaluate_models() calculate model error run select best results. Let’s load basic model generated last article.
code: data("base_dat", package = "ConFluxPro") mod_pf <- pro_flux(base_dat)

title: Calibration
text: given model, can generate run_map, plan modify model run function cfp_run_map(). now consider method = "random" variant, parameter values run randomly sampled. requires input parameters. First, need select parameters want modify. parameters must come soilphys dataset. Keep number parameters low, many degrees freedom may prevent approach converge specific parameter set. Furthermore, different uncertainties can balanced modifying single parameter. example, high SWC can compensated lower TPS vice versa. select adapt TPS within layer. also need tell function, range want modify parameter modify . , different options. can either give specified range absolute values, type = "abs", subtract add certain amount original value type = "addition" multiply given factor type = "factor". now, let’s select type = "factor", let TPS modify 90-110 % original value. provide information named list param argument. names list represent columns soilphys limits given vector length 2. type modification given type, vector length params. last thing now provide number model runs generate providing integer number n_runs. valid object class cfp_run_map. object data.frame new run identified column run_id. can see new row run, value TPS multiplied . case, TPS entire profile modified factor run. can also select, parameters within layer modified independent another. generates new TPS factor layer layers_map. take look run_map , now see multiple rows run_id different value layer. can extract different parameters modified within run_map cfp_params_df(). shows mapping parameter identifier (param_id). layers_different = TRUE, parameter new layer param_id. can also define layers different source, either soilphys providing custom data.frame. example, example dataset, TPS changes four layers within soilphys. Assuming measurements TPS, makes sense vary TPS within boundaries well. , first set layers_from = "layers_altmap" provide new cfp_layers_map(), defines layers parameter variation. look result cfp_params_df() , can see now one parameter layer site. total vary eight parameters. providing layers_altmap, can also specify distinct limits layer individually. Let’s say measurement TPS lower soil lower variation topsoil. can generate different limits within layer: now tell cfp_run_map use columns layers_altmap new limits. change numeric limits (c(0.9, 1.1) character vector specifying columns values stored c("TPS_min", "TPS_max"). Depending setting layers_from, function search columns respective dataset. new values provided actual TPS values, factors, also adjust type "abs". Whichever run_map generated, next step apply modify model. happens within function alternate(), discussed now.

what: General workflow and uncertainty from gasdata
title: Uncertainty estimation
text: relevant source uncertainty FGM-based models input parameters. Especially parameters related estimation calculation diffusion coefficient DS hard measure soil heterogeneity introduces uncertainty. ’ll use example dataset demonstrate effect. dataset, molar fraction CO2 measured three replicates depth within soil. normal model, use replicates fit single profile. randomly sampling replicates, can estimate uncertainty concentration profiles measurement introduces model. can done bootstrap_error() n_samples = 25 created 25 new models. , random selection measured x_ppm values created per profile. done resampling number observations depth allowing replacing (meaning single measurement may sampled multiple times!). extract efflux, now get second column DELTA_efflux gives uncertainty. Notice, value efflux changed slightly original model. now estimated mean value 25 models, standard deviation estimate DELTA_efflux. Similarly, can extract production(), respective columns also added.
code: data("base_dat", package = "ConFluxPro") mod_pf <- pro_flux(base_dat) set.seed(42) # to get exactly same result every time  mod_pf_bs_gasdata <-    bootstrap_error(mod_pf,                    n_samples = 25,                    sample_from = "gasdata") #>  #> validating datasets #> id_cols: site, Date, gas, bootstrap_id #> 600 unique profiles ## after bootstrapping mod_pf_bs_gasdata %>%   filter(prof_id == 1) %>%   efflux() #>  #> A cfp_profile object  #> id_cols: site Date gas  #> 1  unique profiles  #>  #>     site       Date gas    efflux prof_id DELTA_efflux #> 1 site_a 2021-01-01 CO2 0.8336188       1   0.01934041  ## originial model mod_pf %>%   filter(prof_id == 1) %>%   efflux() #>  #> A cfp_profile object  #> id_cols: site Date gas  #> 1  unique profiles  #>  #>     site       Date gas    efflux prof_id #> 1 site_a 2021-01-01 CO2 0.8347288       1 mod_pf_bs_gasdata %>%   filter(prof_id == 1) %>%   production() #>  #> A cfp_layered_profile object  #> id_cols: site Date gas  #> 1  unique profiles  #>  #>     site       Date gas upper lower layer   prod_abs  prod_rel    efflux F0 #> 1 site_a 2021-01-01 CO2     0  -100     1 0.09728528 0.1167024 0.8336188  0 #> 2 site_a 2021-01-01 CO2     5     0     2 0.73633354 0.8832976 0.8336188  0 #>   DELTA_F0 DELTA_prod_abs DELTA_prod_rel #> 1       NA    0.003887647    0.007371137 #> 2       NA    0.022983446    0.048063678

text: However, gas concentration data carries uncertainty. Indeed, many parameters contained within soilphys dataset subject significant uncertainty due sampling error soil heterogeneity. present dataset represented . , let’s pretend measured TPS three replicates identified replicate_id spread around mean. randomly sampling normal distribution standard deviation 0.01. Now can create new dataset includes new values TPS create cfp_pfmod model. course use real measurements instead include variability parameters (SWC, t, …) well. don’t call pro_flux(), don’t want calulcate result replication individual. Now can run bootstrap_error() . time, tell function resample soilphys dataset creating bootstrapping runs. , need tell id_cols define(s) replications dataset. case, replicate_id. , single value profile depth sampled run. new call looks like : take look result efflux() , can see uncertainty efflux estimate increased compared using variability gasdata. Finally, can also use variability datasets time. runs sampling strategies independent another.
code: library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following object is masked from 'package:ConFluxPro': #>  #>     n_groups #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union soilphys <- cfp_soilphys(base_dat)  set.seed(42) soilphys_replicate_TPS <- soilphys %>%   # get base TPS info   select(site, upper, lower, TPS) %>%   distinct() %>%   rename(TPS_mean = TPS) %>%   # repeat each row 3 times    cross_join(data.frame(replicate_id = 1:3)) %>%   # generate new, random TPS values   mutate(TPS = rnorm(n(), TPS_mean, 0.01)) %>%   # join with rest of dataset   left_join(soilphys %>% select(!TPS),             by = c("site", "upper", "lower"),             relationship = "many-to-many") %>%   # recaluclate DS and c_air   complete_soilphys(DSD0_formula = "a*AFPS^b", quiet = TRUE) %>%   cfp_soilphys(id_cols = c("site", "Date", "replicate_id")) #>  #> added 'gas' to id_cols replicate_dat <-    cfp_dat(cfp_gasdata(base_dat),           soilphys_replicate_TPS,           cfp_layers_map(base_dat)) #>  #> validating datasets #> id_cols: site, Date, gas, replicate_id #> 72 unique profiles  mod_pf_replicate <-   cfp_pfmod(replicate_dat) set.seed(42) mod_pf_bs_soilphys <-    bootstrap_error(mod_pf_replicate,                    n_samples = 25,                    sample_from = "soilphys",                   rep_cols = "replicate_id") #>  #> validating datasets #> id_cols: site, Date, gas, bootstrap_id #> 600 unique profiles #>  #> validating datasets #> id_cols: site, Date, gas #> 24 unique profiles ## boostrapping from soilphys mod_pf_bs_soilphys %>%   filter(prof_id < 10) %>%   efflux() #>  #> A cfp_profile object  #> id_cols: site Date gas  #> 9  unique profiles  #>  #>     site       Date gas    efflux prof_id DELTA_efflux #> 1 site_a 2021-01-01 CO2 0.8284734       1   0.02369963 #> 2 site_b 2021-01-01 CO2 0.6809739       2   0.01377851 #> 3 site_a 2021-02-01 CO2 1.3522946       3   0.04108327 #> 4 site_b 2021-02-01 CO2 1.0733001       4   0.02497279 #> 5 site_a 2021-03-01 CO2 1.7396562       5   0.04583895 #> 6 site_b 2021-03-01 CO2 1.3916118       6   0.04032870 #> 7 site_a 2021-04-01 CO2 4.0887068       7   0.10509266 #> 8 site_b 2021-04-01 CO2 3.3623254       8   0.04875499 #> 9 site_a 2021-05-01 CO2 5.8339197       9   0.16272032  ## boostrapping from gasdata mod_pf_bs_gasdata %>%   filter(prof_id < 10) %>%   efflux() #>  #> A cfp_profile object  #> id_cols: site Date gas  #> 9  unique profiles  #>  #>     site       Date gas    efflux prof_id DELTA_efflux #> 1 site_a 2021-01-01 CO2 0.8336188       1  0.019340412 #> 2 site_b 2021-01-01 CO2 0.6816792       2  0.016291276 #> 3 site_a 2021-02-01 CO2 1.3745789       3  0.017921161 #> 4 site_b 2021-02-01 CO2 1.0611182       4  0.012922019 #> 5 site_a 2021-03-01 CO2 1.7370006       5  0.038777233 #> 6 site_b 2021-03-01 CO2 1.3863835       6  0.009591992 #> 7 site_a 2021-04-01 CO2 4.1470956       7  0.047504882 #> 8 site_b 2021-04-01 CO2 3.3411440       8  0.047524641 #> 9 site_a 2021-05-01 CO2 5.9591679       9  0.063722814 set.seed(42) mod_pf_bs_both <-    bootstrap_error(mod_pf_replicate,                    n_samples = 25,                    sample_from = "both",                   rep_cols = "replicate_id") #>  #> validating datasets #> id_cols: site, Date, gas, bootstrap_id #> 600 unique profiles #>  #> validating datasets #> id_cols: site, Date, gas #> 24 unique profiles mod_pf_bs_both %>%   filter(prof_id < 10) %>%   efflux() #>  #> A cfp_profile object  #> id_cols: site Date gas  #> 9  unique profiles  #>  #>     site       Date gas    efflux prof_id DELTA_efflux #> 1 site_a 2021-01-01 CO2 0.8240803       1   0.03005396 #> 2 site_b 2021-01-01 CO2 0.6831012       2   0.02640363 #> 3 site_a 2021-02-01 CO2 1.3486770       3   0.03307125 #> 4 site_b 2021-02-01 CO2 1.0755834       4   0.02088252 #> 5 site_a 2021-03-01 CO2 1.7209752       5   0.06241706 #> 6 site_b 2021-03-01 CO2 1.3986402       6   0.03195282 #> 7 site_a 2021-04-01 CO2 4.0818567       7   0.10536313 #> 8 site_b 2021-04-01 CO2 3.4030107       8   0.09897170 #> 9 site_a 2021-05-01 CO2 5.8525804       9   0.16324836

what: A Toolkit for Soil Gas Analysis
title: A Toolkit for Soil Gas Analysis
text: ConFluxPro free toolbox modelling soil gas fluxes using Flux Gradient Method (FGM). provides functions data preparation, framework model set-implements different FGM models, including inverse approach.

title: A Toolkit for Soil Gas Analysis
text: can install latest release CRAN: Install current development version github: get started, check provided vignette installation:
code: install.packages("ConFluxPro") # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("valentingar/ConFluxPro", build_vignettes = TRUE, dependencies = TRUE) vignette("ConFluxPro",package = "ConFluxPro")

title: A Toolkit for Soil Gas Analysis
text: Flux Gradient Method (FGM) calculates diffusive flux rates FF gases vertical concentration gradients dc/dzdc/dz soil air apparent diffusion coefficient coefficient DsD_s. F=−Ds⋅dcdz F= -D_s\cdot \frac{dc}{dz} FGM excellent alternative methods, Eddy-Covariance chamber measurements, can costly work intensive. measuring concentration gradients soil deriving apparent diffusion coefficient soil physical parameters, continuous low-impact measurement soil gas fluxes vertical production profiles possible. basic calculation fluxes may simple, FGM requires combination different datasets varying methods. ConFluxPro comes . package can help easily process raw data, combine datasets set different model variants straightforward reproducible manner. background, see review method can deployed especially long-term monitoring soil gas fluxes.

title: A Toolkit for Soil Gas Analysis
text: central idea ConFluxPro distinct profile, .e. single time point given site given gas, can uniquely identified set columns called id_cols. Different classes help set validate datasets: cfp_gasdata() data.frame profile concentration data column x_ppm different depths column depth. cfp_soilphys() data.frame soil physical information. profile split layers defined upper lower boundary, without gaps overlaps. layer least information density air c_air diffusion coefficient DS given gas. cfp_layers_map() data.frame layered similarly gives information model structure, .e. layers production rate calculated. three datasets combined central data class cfp_dat(), automatically adjusted correctly match . object contains necessary information.
code: gasdata <- cfp_gasdata(ConFluxPro::gasdata,                        id_cols = c("site", "Date")) #>  #> added 'gas' to id_cols  soilphys <- cfp_soilphys(ConFluxPro::soilphys,                          id_cols = c("site", "Date")) #>  #> added 'gas' to id_cols  layers_map <- cfp_layers_map(   data.frame(site = rep(c("site_a", "site_b"), each = 3),              upper = c(5,   0,  -20, 7,   0,  -20),              lower = c(0, -20, -100, 0, -20, -100)),   gas = "CO2",    lowlim = 0,    highlim = 1000,   id_cols = "site") #>  #> added 'gas' to id_cols my_dat <- cfp_dat(gasdata, soilphys, layers_map) my_dat #>  #> A cfp_dat object to be used as input in ConFluxPro models.  #> id_cols: site Date gas  #> number of profiles:  24  #> number of groups:  2

title: A Toolkit for Soil Gas Analysis
text: cfp_dat() object created successfully, modelling easy: modelling function can adapted different needs. example, can provide different modes argument fg_flux() calculate concentration gradient form exponential fit instead linear model. result cases object contains original data my_dat flux rates different soil layers profiles identified cfp_dat(). , soil/atmosphere efflux rate specific production rate model soil layer can extracted. case forward model FLUX, may require consideration method extrapolation used (see manual ?efflux), different approaches implemented. efflux() returns data.frame one row per profile corresponding efflux rate.
code: # 'normal' forward model FLUX <- fg_flux(my_dat) # inverse model PROFLUX <- pro_flux(my_dat) FLUX <- fg_flux(my_dat, modes = "EF") # soil/atmosphere efflux efflux(FLUX) efflux(PROFLUX)  # per-layer production rate production(FLUX) production(PROFLUX) library(ggplot2) efflux(PROFLUX) %>%   ggplot(aes(x = Date, y = efflux, col = site))+   geom_line()+   scale_color_viridis_d()+   scale_x_date(date_minor_breaks = "1 month")+   ylab(expression("CO"[2]~"efflux ["*mu*"mol m"^"-2"~"s"^"-1"*"]"))+   theme_minimal()

title: Calculate DSD0 — DSD0
text: Different functions estimate soil diffusivity air-filled pore space.

title: Calculate DSD0 — DSD0
code: DSD0_millington_quirk(AFPS, TPS = NULL, tortuosity = NULL)  DSD0_moldrup(AFPS, AFPS_100, b_campbell)  DSD0_currie(AFPS, a_currie = 1.9, b_currie = 1.4)  DSD0_linear(AFPS, a_lin, b_lin)

title: Calculate DSD0 — DSD0
text: AFPS air-filled porosity. TPS Total pore space tortuosity tortuosity soil AFPS_100 Air filled porosity -100cm soil water matric head. b_campbell Campbell (1974) PSD index a_currie, b_currie fit parameter Currie-style models a_lin, b_lin linear model coefficients

title: Calculate DSD0 — DSD0
text: numeric vector DSD0.

title: Calculate DSD0 — DSD0
text: DSD0_millington_quirk() form \(D_s / D_0 = \Xi \cdot \epsilon\) \(\Xi\) tortuosity factor (tortuosity) calulcated \(\Xi = \frac{\epsilon^{(10/3)}}{\Phi^2}\) ; \(\epsilon\) air-filled pore space (AFPS) \(\Phi\) porosity (TPS). Millington & Quirk (1961). DSD0_moldrup() form \(D_s / D_0 = (2 \cdot \epsilon_{100}^3 + 0.04 \cdot \epsilon_{100}) \cdot (\frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon_{100}})^{(2 + \frac{3}{b_{campbell}})}\) \(\epsilon_{100}\) air-filled pore space matric potential head -100 cm \(b_{campbell}\) slope water retention curve. Moldrup et al. (2000). DSD0_currie() form \(D_s / D_0 = \cdot \epsilon^b\) \(\) \(b\) fit parameter exponential model. Currie (1960) default values (=1.9; b=1.4)Troeh (1982). DSD0_linear() linear model form \(D_s / D_0 = \cdot \epsilon + b\).

title: Calculate DSD0 — DSD0
text: Millington, R. J., & Quirk, J. P. (1961). Permeability porous solids. Transactions Faraday Society (Vol. 57, p. 1200). Royal Society Chemistry (RSC). https://doi.org/10.1039/tf9615701200 Moldrup, P., Olesen, T., Schjønning, P., Yamaguchi, T., & Rolston, D. E. (2000). Predicting Gas Diffusion Coefficient Undisturbed Soil Soil Water Characteristics. Soil Science Society America Journal (Vol. 64, Issue 1, pp. 94–100). Wiley. https://doi.org/10.2136/sssaj2000.64194x Currie, J. . (1960). Gaseous diffusion porous media. Part 2. - Dry granular materials. British Journal Applied Physics (Vol. 11, Issue 8, pp. 318–324). IOP Publishing. https://doi.org/10.1088/0508-3443/11/8/303 Troeh, F. R., Jabro, J. D., & Kirkham, D. (1982). Gaseous diffusion equations porous materials. Geoderma (Vol. 27, Issue 3, pp. 239–253). Elsevier BV. https://doi.org/10.1016/0016-7061(82)90033-7

title: Model frame for fg_flux — cfp_fgmod
text: x cfp_dat object necessary input datasets. gases (character) character vector defining gases fluxes shall calculated. modes (character) character vector specifying mode(s) dcdz calculation. Can "LL","LS","EF". LL local linear approach: within layer linear model evaluated concentration depth. LS linear spline approach: linear spline fitted complete profile nodes layer intersections. EF exponential fit approach: exponential function form y=+b*x^c fit concentration depth. Using first derivative function concentration gradient evaluated layer. DA exponential fit approach: exponential function form y=+b*(1-exp(-*x)) fit concentration depth. Using first derivative function concentration gradient evaluated layer. Davidson (2006). param (character) vector containing parameters soilphys, means calculated, must contain "c_air" "DS", parameters may help interpretation. funs (character) vector defining type mean used parameter param. One "arith" "harm".

title: Model frame for fg_flux — cfp_fgmod

title: Model frame for fg_flux — cfp_fgmod

what: Add lowlim and highlim for multiple gases
title: Model layers — cfp_layers_map
text: Sometimes practical model different gases different limits. example, reasonable assumption CO2 consumed relevant amounts soils, whereas CH4 may produced consumed. Therefore may want limit production rates CO2 positive values, whereas allowing negative CH4 production rates (.e. consumption) well. make setup easy, can provide gas vector function together highlim lowlim vectors length. provided layers_map data.frame replicated gas respective values production limits provided.

what: Interpolate over depth to layered profile — discretize_depth
title: Interpolate over depth to layered profile — discretize_depth
text: Interpolate discretize data layered structure. output data.frame profile separated layers intersect depths defined function call. See cfp_layered_profile(). different interpolation methods implemented, might practical different parameters tasks. 'linear' interpolation continuous parameters, (e.g. soil temperature). 'boundary' interpolation suitable data already layered. selects value old layer new layer lay . 'linspline' interpolation fits linear spline model data knots defined  knots 'nearest' finds closest value new layer. can define whether closest value nearest top 1, bottom 0 layer using int_depth 'harmonic' similar linear interpolation uses harmonic mean harm() using distance depth value weights. Multiple variables can discretized time supplying multiple column names param. also possible use different method controlling parameters int_depth knots param. Just provide list settings length param. one value given, multiple param settings reused parameter.

title: Interpolate over depth to layered profile — discretize_depth

Must order param. One linear boundary linspline nearest harmonic depth_target (numeric vector data frame) specifying new layers. Must include n+1 depths n target layers. target layers different id_cols, enter data.frame instead. data frame must "depth" column, well well id_cols needed must least subset id_cols original data. boundary_nearest (logical) = TRUE/FALSE TRUE target depth steps (partially) outside parameter boundaries, nearest neighbor returned, else returns NA. Default FALSE. boundary_average ("character) Defines happens new layer contains multiple old layers. one none = default  new layer set NA arith new layer calculated arithmetic mean old harm new layer calculated harmonic mean old int_depth (numeric vector)  = value 0 1 1 = interpolation takes top depth step, 0.5 = middle 0= bottom. Default = 0.5 knots (numeric vector) = depths knots 'linspline' method placed. differs parameters, list numeric vectors length "param" can provided. differ id_cols. ... title: Flux-gradient method — fg_flux
text: fg_flux() implements different approaches flux-gradient method (FGM). takes valid input dataset cfp_dat() calculates layer defined cfp_layers_map().

title: Flux-gradient method — fg_flux
code: fg_flux(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'cfp_dat' fg_flux(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'cfp_fgres' fg_flux(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'cfp_fgmod' fg_flux(x, ...)

title: Flux-gradient method — fg_flux
text: x cfp_dat object necessary input datasets. ... Arguments passed cfp_fgmod gases (character) character vector defining gases fluxes shall calculated. modes (character) character vector specifying mode(s) dcdz calculation. Can "LL","LS","EF". LL local linear approach: within layer linear model evaluated concentration depth. LS linear spline approach: linear spline fitted complete profile nodes layer intersections. EF exponential fit approach: exponential function form y=+b*x^c fit concentration depth. Using first derivative function concentration gradient evaluated layer. DA exponential fit approach: exponential function form y=+b*(1-exp(-*x)) fit concentration depth. Using first derivative function concentration gradient evaluated layer. Davidson (2006). param (character) vector containing parameters soilphys, means calculated, must contain "c_air" "DS", parameters may help interpretation. funs (character) vector defining type mean used parameter param. One "arith" "harm".

title: Extract production rates — production
text: pro_flux() model, extraction straightforward simply product optimised production rate (per volume) multiplied height layer. fg_flux(), assumption made production layer \(\) difference flux layer \(F_{+1}\) layer \(F_{-1}\). flux lowest layer assumed zero flux topmost layer efflux. approach uncertainties evaluated applies model. error estimates available call bootstrap_error(), errors propagated follows: $$\Delta prod_{rel} = |\Delta efflux \cdot \frac{prod_{abs}}{efflux^2}| + |\Delta prod_{abs}\cdot\frac{1}{efflux}|$$

text: Azzini, Ivano; Mara, Thierry .; Rosati, Rossana: Comparison two sets Monte Carlo estimators Sobol’ indices, Environmental Modelling & Software, Volume 144, 2021, 105167, ISSN 1364-8152, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.envsoft.2021.105167

title: Calculate sobol indices — sobol_calc_indices
code: if (FALSE) { # interactive() PROFLUX <- pro_flux(base_dat)  sobol_map <- sobol_run_map(PROFLUX,  params = list("TPS" = c(0.9, 1.1),                "t" = c(0.9, 1.1)),  type = c("factor", "factor"),  n_runs = 10)   PF_sobol <- alternate(   PROFLUX,   \(x) complete_soilphys(x, DSD0_formula = "a*AFPS^b", quiet = TRUE),   sobol_map)  sobol_calc_indices(efflux(PF_sobol), "efflux", c("site"), sobol_map)  }

text: soilphys (dataframe) soilphys dataframe layers_map (dataframe) containing following parameters: upper upper limit layer cm lower lower limit layer cm layer name layer ... id_cols necessary param (character vector) vector containing names variables soilphys carried funs (character vector) vector defining type mean used. title: soilphys_layered — soilphys_layered
text: soilphys, reduced id_cols param columns summarised layers provided layers_map

title: soilphys_layered — soilphys_layered
code: data(soildiff) layers_map <- data.frame(site = rep(c("site_a",                                       "site_b"),each = 2),                          upper = c(5,0,7,0),                          lower = c(0,-100,0,-100),                          layer = rep(c("HU","M1"),times = 2) )  soildiff$depth <- (soildiff$upper + soildiff$lower) / 2  soilphys_layered(soilphys = soildiff,                  layers_map = layers_map,                  param = c("TPS","a"),                  funs = c("harm","arith"),                  id_cols = c("site")) #> # A tibble: 4 × 6 #> # Groups:   site [2] #>   site   layer   TPS     a upper lower #>   <chr>  <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 site_a HU    0.84   0.35     5     0 #> 2 site_a M1    0.397  1.15     0  -100 #> 3 site_b HU    0.8    0.4      7     0 #> 4 site_b M1    0.305  1.03     0  -100
